text: I can tell you that what would be an
absolute deal breaker for us is that we
would not accept as liberal democrats
under any circumstances the cuts to
nurseries and schools and colleges to
education that both the conservative and
the Labour Party's have now announced we
would not accept that under any
circumstance that would be a deal
breaker we would insist that there is a
proper protection for the money going to
nursery schools and colleges in any
Parliament of which the Liberal
Democrats are apart and if we don't get
that we wouldn't enter into the
coalition in the first place but both
the Conservatives and the Labour Party
have pledged to protect education
spending so how are you going further
because they haven't they're just
basically fibbing to the British people
the Conservatives have said they'll keep
funding in pace with the increase in
pupil numbers but they won't increase it
in line with prices and labored on the
reverse they'll say they'll increase it
in line with prices but not with pupil
numbers there are 400,000 youngsters new
youngsters extra youngsters they're
going to come into our education system
so by the end of the next parliament you
need to do both and only the Liberal
Democrats are now saying that will
protect funding from cradle to college
we've put it on the front page of our
manifesto and the Liberal Democrats will
not enter into any coalition that
doesn't guarantee that that money that
protection for our education system from
cradle to college from nursery to 19
year olds is not is not protected how
much more does that mean you will be
spending on education compared to the
Labour plans or the conservative plans
so in pounds and pence it means that by
the end of the next parliament per year
we would be spending two and a half
billion pounds more on education
spending than the Labour Party and five
billion pounds more than the
Conservatives that is a significant
difference in total we would be spending
roughly in total about 55 billion pounds
on our education system and both the
Labour the conservative parties have
confirmed that they will spend less I
think that is wrong the Liberal
Democrats believe in beyond everything
else in the in the in the need to spread
opportunity across society and you can
only do that if you continue to invest
in not cut the money that goes
especially into nurseries preschool
support schools and college
extra spending on education presumably
means that for non-protected departments
like defense like the police that means
your pledge on education will mean more
cuts for those departments what we
believe is that if you want to get this
balance right of wiping the slate clean
for the next generation balancing the
books and doing so fairly its first
you've got to do it on time in a timely
fashion not string it out like the
Labour Party want to which ironically
means actually you preside over many
more years of cuts than under the
Liberal Democrat plan but also that you
ask the wealthiest to pay an extra
contribution through the tax system and
that's why we are asking the wealthiest
those were the broader shoulders to pay
a bit of extra money through the tax
system to help balance the books and
ensure that we can put money into the
putt into our public services into our
nurseries into our schools and into our
colleges neither labor nor the
conservative parties want to do that
labour wants to stick its head in the
sand and won't tell you when they'll
balance the books by and the
Conservatives won't ask the wealthiest
to make any additional contribution only
through a balanced approach can you
finish the job of filling the black hole
in our public finances but also invest
in public services
